H0.text: Gradual climate change is the most likely cause of the large number of species on Earth that became extinct during a short time period about 65 million years ago.

H1.text: Continued climate stability is the most likely cause of the mass extinction that occurred about 65 million years ago, during which a large number of species on Earth became extinct in a short time period.

H2.text: Sudden global climate change is the most likely cause of the large number of species on Earth that became extinct during the short time period about 65 million years ago.

H3.text: Gradual ecosystem succession is the most likely cause of the mass extinction that occurred about 65 million years ago, during which a large number of species on Earth became extinct in a short time period.

A4.text: The Chicxulub asteroid impact event rapidly acidified the oceans and produced long‑lasting effects on the climate.

A5.text: Species that depended on photosynthesis declined or became extinct as atmospheric particles blocked sunlight and reduced the solar energy reaching the ground.
